awd_titl_txt: CISE-ANR: FET: Small: Hybrid Stochastic Tunnel Junction Circuits for Optimization and Inference
awd_abstract_narration:
Neuroscience research shows that pervasive randomness in brains is fundamental to their stability and computational ability. This observation inspires probabilistic models that are useful for a variety of learning and optimization tasks. Conventional computers are not well suited to solving such problems because they are fundamentally deterministic. In this work, the researchers propose to develop probabilistic unit cells by augmenting commercial computer chips with thermally unstable magnetic devices that naturally exhibit probabilistic behavior. Distributed networks of such devices will enable emulating and accelerating powerful stochastic computational models.  
Reverse engineering the brain is one of the major challenges of the 21st century. Such an endeavor will undoubtedly affect the way computation is understood.  This proposal, inspired by a probabilistic interpretation of neural activity will develop a hybrid probabilistic technology as a prototype to efficiently transfer this insight into a tangible technology and then to the broader community. The research will require contributions of a diverse international team from a variety of fields such as material science, device physics, electrical engineering, and computer science. The results of this research will be disseminated in the form of publications, presentations, short pedagogical YouTube videos in various languages, and lab tours for the general public.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this work was to explore the use of novel, complementary-metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) compatible memory technologies such as magnetic tunnel junctions, for computational tasks. Conventionally used as digital memories, with high barriers between the states to be stored, lower barrier and oscillator versions of these technologies can be used to generate truly random numbers. Random number/bit generation is an important requirement for next-generation computing systems that are specially built to solve complex optimization problems. The way such computers work is by encoding a problem that needs to be solved into a energy function that needs to be maximized/minimized. Effectively searching for the minimum of such an energy function requires generating a lot of random bits/sec which is inefficient to do with modern digital computing hardware.

 

Towards that end we have made positive steps in three major directions.

First, we have been able to use the physical phenomenon of frequency locking between an externally applied reference signal and a spin torque nano-oscillator oscillating at half the frequency to generate a random bit-stream. During the frequency-locking process, there are thermally generated phase slips between the magnetic nano-oscillator and the reference frequency which can be measured and read out on an oscilloscope. Due to the intrinsic balance of such a phase-locking process, the bit-stream generated is unbiased and truly random. Our numerical simulations exhibit excellent agreement with the experimental results, confirming the robustness and viability of our approach.

 

Second, we have been able to develop a compact model for the random telegraph fluctuations that are exhibited by low barrier version of memory class magnetic tunnel junctions. Since these devices are the flagship technology for probabilistic computing approaches, coming up with a model at the right degree of complexity is an important task. Micromagnetic simulations, which are the most complex models that use fine-grained details of magnetic structure to describe the dynamics of the system, are slow and tedious, while simple Neel Brown models are fast but do not capture the device statistics and dynamics in a way amenable for circuit simulation. In this work we develop an experimentally parameterizable, empirically driven, compact model which is fast due to its low dimensionality while still capturing most of the essential physics required for circuit simulations.  

 

Third, we have been able to demonstrate for the first time, tunable analog interaction between two superparamagnetic tunnel junctions with a scalable circuit that can perform simulated-annealing-like operations. With this circuit, we were able to experimentally couple two devices with widely varying device properties. These tunable coupling circuits can achieve the whole range of correlations from −1 to 1 for both devices with similar time scales and devices whose time scales vary by an order of magnitude. This paves the way for making all-to-all connected kernels that can be used in crossbar implementations of next-generation computing systems built to solve combinatorial optimization problems.

 

This work was performed in collaboration with SPINTEC, a leading spintronics research laboratory based in Grenoble, France, The National Institute of Standards and Technology, based in Gaithersburg Maryland, and the University of Maryland at College Park. This work has enabled the education of 4 PhD students, three of which have been working in an experimental capacity and one in a theoretical capacity. The results of this work have been published in leading Physics journals, presented at various international conferences, and invited to be discussed in labs across Europe and the United States.
